title: Will Airbus Build The A380neo? - Simple Flying
description:
The Airbus A380 is a huge plane, being the only fully double-decker jet airliner in commercial service today.
The question is, are these benefits enough to justify Airbus creating a modern version of the A380, complete with all the efficiency-increasing technological advantages that modern jetliners such as the Airbus A350 benefit from?
Thanks to some news from earlier this year, there may be some hope for Airbus creating the A380neo.
Previously, the last news about the potential for an A380neo hitting the market was in 2018, when there was speculation that Lufthansa would be purchasing 15 A380neo aircraft, adding perceived momentum to the project, but this turned out to be wishful thinking.
According to Clark, his plans for the A380neo would include many similarities with the modern long-range aircraft that dominate the medium-to-long-haul market today, such as the Boeing 787 and Airbus A350.
text:
The Airbus A380 is a huge plane, being the only fully double-decker jet airliner in commercial service today. As the world's largest passenger airliner, it can potentially transport around 800 passengers in a single configuration over very long routes. To utilize the huge passenger-carrying potential the aircraft has, airports need to specially upgrade their gates and other infrastructure in order to accommodate the A380's massive wingspan and weight. Additionally, airlines have to pay expensive fuel costs due to the A380 being less efficient than smaller planes.

As a trade-off, the A380 is unmatched for dense hub-to-hub passenger routes, and traveling on the plane is regarded by passengers as a unique experience. The question is, are these benefits enough to justify Airbus creating a modern version of the A380, complete with all the efficiency-increasing technological advantages that modern jetliners such as the Airbus A350 benefit from? Thanks to some news from earlier this year, there may be some hope for Airbus creating the A380neo.

Emirates Will Buy The A380neo If It's Built

The news on this subject is that, in January this year, Emirates president Sir Tim Clark communicated his interest in the project, recounting a conversation between himself and Airbus executives about the possibility of the A380neo project being undertaken, according to Executive Traveller. A modern version of the A380 would be able to take advantage of the latest technology, giving the new A380neo a better chance of success than its predecessor. Clark said the following to the publication during a trip to Melbourne on an A380:

“I still have a design in front of Airbus as to how they could build a new one which would be 25% cheaper to run, far more fuel-efficient than this one. They said, ‘Well if you give us €20 billion, we’ll do it for you!’”

Clark recounted his reply that it was up to Airbus to make that large investment, but also committed to buying the aircraft if they do: “but if you build them, we’ll buy them.” Clark’s blueprint for the A380neo would deliver at least a 20-25% reduction in fuel, according to him, and he believes this would make all the difference in making the large, four-engined double-decker jet viable in today's commercial aviation market.

Previously, the last news about the potential for an A380neo hitting the market was in 2018, when there was speculation that Lufthansa would be purchasing 15 A380neo aircraft, adding perceived momentum to the project, but this turned out to be wishful thinking. A couple of years later, COVID and lockdowns caused a contraction of the aviation market, which has since returned to normal. In a struggle to meet quickly rising demand, airlines have had to start looking for solutions.

What Changes Would An A380neo Have?

According to Clark, his plans for the A380neo would include many similarities with the modern long-range aircraft that dominate the medium-to-long-haul market today, such as the Boeing 787 and Airbus A350. He specified some of these in the Executive Traveller article:

“We now know a lot more about the A380 than we did when it was built. The (tail) fin is too large, the wings need to be changed… all of this is in the later generation of aircraft.”

The extensive use of carbon fiber composites was also specified, as both the 787 and A350 feature at least 50% composites in the fuselage and wings. Typically, composites have a greater strength-to-weight ratio compared to typical aluminum alloys, significantly improving lightness and fuel-efficiency. Since the A380 has such expansively wide wings, its usability could also be increased by featuring similar folding wingtips to the Boeing 777X, meaning it could utilize normal airport gates, but this was not one of Clark's suggestions as far as is known.

The largest impact in terms of achieving better fuel-efficiency would be through the use of modern high-bypass turbofan engines, and Clark is hopeful that four Rolls-Royce UltraFan engines, which are currently being developed by Rolls-Royce, may fit the bill.

“If it’s ever allowed to get its head above the water level, this is a revolution in power. It’s a much bigger fan requiring less fuel to drive it, with enormous thrust capabilities (so) you’ve got to get something like that on the A380.”

With a fan diameter of 140 inches, the UltraFan is set to be the biggest and most efficient turbofan engine ever. Expected to begin air and ground testing by 2030, the engine will be capable of using 100% Sustainable Aviation Fuel from day one, and Rolls-Royce is even exploring options for hybrid-electric and hydrogen power solutions.

The A380neo Would Be Well-Loved

Passengers would certainly welcome the return of the A380, which is regarded as being the best for its premium passenger experience, featuring private first-class suites equipped with showers and a cocktail bar at the rear of the upper deck. For airlines, the A380 is desirable for its ability to transport many customers, and as a result, airlines such as Qantas have started bringing their A380's out of retirement, according to AirwaysMag.

The A380 is also famous in Hollywood, having been the inspiration for the fictional double-decker where the 2005 movie, Flightplan, takes place. However, in the film, some of the internal space, such as in avionics, is larger for effect. In a thread, Simple Flying asked whether Airbus should build the A380neo, and received a good number of responses, many making the case for viability in today's market:

"A combination of slot restrictions, population growth and the obvious indicators that some airlines CAN make quad retest work, a VLA will be needed soon. A relaunched NEO A380 with aerodynamic improvements would be very welcome."

"Yes, for sure. With composites, better and more fuel efficient engines it's therefore a no brainer. The current fact of crowded skies and airports will dictate planes having nowhere to land. Fewer, larger planes are the future."

There were also people of the opinion that such a large plane in this day and age would be impractical, thanks to only being able to use a limited number of airstrips and gates, favoring aircraft that were able to use more locations instead:

"Put simply, there isn’t enough infrastructure to support a new generation of A380 aircraft. The A380 is already restricted to larger airports, and with more absurdly large aircraft in the ecosystem, there’s just no more room! Don’t get me wrong, the A380 is an incredible feat of human engineering, but it’s replacement by more versatile aircraft like the B787 is inevitable. Air France for example, has retired it’s A380 fleet even though they were only 15 years old."

Are Smaller Aircraft The Future?

It is a good observation that the commercial aviation market has recently been dominated by much smaller widebody aircraft than the A380. Using the most recent Airbus A350-900ULR variant as an example, the aircraft operates the longest flights in the world, Singapore Airlines Flights 23 and 24 from Singapore to New York JFK, as of 2022.

Range is the reason why aircraft such as the A350 have dominated, as it gives airlines the freedom to fly just about any route in the world, while still carrying an impressive 315 people in two-class seating per flight, or 440 as a maximum. For most airlines' purposes, this satisfies the passenger demand for a route, thus it ends up being better value to fly several A350's rather than one A380 flight. This also gives the customer more options for connections and destinations.

However, this may not be the case forever, and if demand continues to grow, the viable niche for ultra-jumbo jetliners will only get larger. In fact, Airbus celebrated the A380's birthday in April, as it had been 20 years since its maiden flight. Since its entry into commercial service, the A380 has flown over 800,000 flights and carried more than 300 million passengers, according to Airbus, and the manufacturer intends to continue supporting the model.

The Idea Has Merit Overall

Originally, Airbus had planned to release more variants of the A380 aside from the -800, the base model. A freight version, the A380F, was canceled in favor of focusing on the -800, and a stretched version, the -900, which would have seated about 656 passengers, or up to 960 passengers in an all-economy configuration, was also canceled. As Clark suspects, “at least a 20-25% reduction in fuel” would be a game-changer for a modern version of the A380, offsetting the main downside of the huge type.

The other large downside, the usability of the plane at airports, could also be easily solved by using folding wings. Thanks to procedures that were polished by manufacturing rival, Boeing and its 777X, Airbus has a test case for a folding-wing commercial aircraft, greatly increasing the potential number of airports that an A380neo could utilize.

Though many believe that this project will never get off the ground, there certainly does exist a niche for the huge luxurious double-decker, particularly if modern fuel-saving measures are used in its design. Emirates has not given up funds to get the project off the ground as yet, but a commitment to buy is very valuable for the manufacturer. It will also be interesting to see whether Airbus gets involved with the UltraFan project with a view to developing another huge quad-jet in the future.

title: KWE and Shell Aviation sign new agreement on the use of SAF - Hydrocarbon Processing
description:
Kintetsu World Express Inc. (KWE) has entered into a new agreement with Shell Aviation, regarding the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
Kintetsu World Express Inc. (KWE) and Shell Aviation jointly participated in the market-based measures framework pilot demonstration program conducted by Smart Freight Centre in 2023.
Under this agreement, KWE will adopt Shell Aviation's digital platform "Avelia" to swiftly address shippers' low-carbon transportation needs.
Avelia will help KWE to access the environmental benefits of SAF even when SAF is not physically available at their locations.
SAF is a key component of our concrete efforts, and our collaboration with Shell Aviation represents a significant step forward for us."
text:
Kintetsu World Express Inc. (KWE) has entered into a new agreement with Shell Aviation, regarding the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

Kintetsu World Express Inc. (KWE) and Shell Aviation jointly participated in the market-based measures framework pilot demonstration program conducted by Smart Freight Centre in 2023. Since then, KWE has been engaged in discussions to establish a secure and convenient mechanism for the use of SAF's environmental benefits by aviation stakeholders, including freight forwarders and shippers, engaging in air freight activities.

Under this agreement, KWE will adopt Shell Aviation's digital platform "Avelia" to swiftly address shippers' low-carbon transportation needs. Avelia will help KWE to access the environmental benefits of SAF even when SAF is not physically available at their locations. It also offers a transparent, secure, and credible blockchain platform that ensures traceability, and helps to prevent erroneous double counting.

Tatsuya Narasaki, Managing Officer at Kintetsu World Express, stated, "We have identified the reduction of CO2 emissions and the promotion of renewable energy use as key sustainability challenges. To mitigate the environmental impact of our global operations, we are working to reduce CO2 emissions not only in Japan but also around the world. We are pleased to announce that our near-term and long-term net-zero emissions reduction targets have been formally approved by SBTi. SAF is a key component of our concrete efforts, and our collaboration with Shell Aviation represents a significant step forward for us."

Doris Tan, Head of Shell Aviation, Asia-Pacific and Middle East, stated, “We value our collaboration with KWE since the early days of the Smart Freight Centre’s market based measures pilot. Through Avelia, we aim to accelerate SAF adoption and provide companies like KWE with a clear, scalable pathway to credible lifecycle GHG emissions reductions (compared to conventional jet fuel) from aviation. This agreement marks another important step in making low-carbon air transport a reality for cargo stakeholders in Asia and beyond."

title: Britain loses another industry after Starmer refuses to step in - The Telegraph
description:
Britain’s largest bioethanol plant will close after Sir Keir Starmer refused to step in and save the industry.
Associated British Foods (ABF), the owner of Vivergo, confirmed on Friday that the plant will shut its doors within weeks.
Sharon Graham, the general secretary, said: “This is a short-sighted decision that totally disregards the benefits the domestic bioethanol sector will bring to jobs and energy security.
The closure of the Vivergo plant will also represent a fresh blow to thousands of British farmers who supply grain to the site.
The UK imports around 45 per cent of its CO2 and sources have previously warned of a supply crisis without a domestic bioethanol industry if foreign sources were disrupted.
text:
Britain’s largest bioethanol plant will close after Sir Keir Starmer refused to step in and save the industry.

On Friday, the Government announced it would not give any funding to the Vivergo Fuels business in Hull, which is losing £3m a month.

Around 150 workers are expected to lose their jobs at the factory, which is expected to close by Sept 13 and is one of only two domestic bioethanol production sites.

Associated British Foods (ABF), the owner of Vivergo, confirmed on Friday that the plant will shut its doors within weeks.

The industry had hoped for a bailout after Sir Keir Starmer’s trade deal with Donald Trump, which will allow the US to supply Britain with 1.4bn litres of duty-free ethanol.

But on Friday afternoon, a government spokesman said: “This Government will always take decisions in the national interest.

“That’s why we negotiated a landmark deal with the US which protected hundreds of thousands of jobs in sectors like auto and aerospace.”

It said it had worked to understand the challenges faced by both Vivergo and the Ensus bioethanol plant in Redcar on Teesside, which has also been refused a bailout.

The spokesman said the Government would not offer any direct funding “as it would not provide value for the taxpayer or solve the long-term problems the industry faces”.

They continued: “We recognise this is a difficult time for the workers and their families and we will work with trade unions, local partners and the companies to support them through this process.

“We also continue to work up proposals that ensure the resilience of our CO2 supply in the long term in consultation with the sector.”

Unite, Labour’s biggest trade union backer, heavily criticised the Government for refusing to bail out the bioethanol industry.

Sharon Graham, the general secretary, said: “This is a short-sighted decision that totally disregards the benefits the domestic bioethanol sector will bring to jobs and energy security.

“Once again, the Government’s total lack of a plan to support oil and gas workers as the industry transitions is glaring.”

The union noted that bioethanol was a key component of sustainable aviation fuel, which is expected to be in huge demand in the coming years.

The closure of the Vivergo plant will also represent a fresh blow to thousands of British farmers who supply grain to the site.

A record number of farms are already closing for good after Rachel Reeves’s changes to agricultural property relief made the future of thousands of rural businesses unviable.

As well as the collapse of a major domestic market, the closure will risk pushing previously profitable farms into making a loss.

An ABF spokesman said: “It is deeply regrettable that the Government has chosen not to support a key national asset.

“We have been fighting for months to keep this plant open. We initiated and led talks with the Government in good faith.

“We presented a clear plan to restore Vivergo to profitability within two years under policy levers already aligned with the Government’s own green industrial strategy.”

ABF accused the Government of having “thrown away billions in potential growth” and the chance to lead the world in bioethanol.

“The loss of Vivergo will be felt most acutely by our dedicated workforce and their families and by the thousands whose livelihoods depend on our supply chain, from farmers to hauliers and engineers.”

During its talks with Jonathan Reynolds, the Business Secretary, ABF had demanded ministers step in to cover “short-term funding of Vivergo’s losses” as well as striking a longer-term deal to put its plant on a profitable footing again.

Investment from Vivergo is thought to support around 1,220 farming jobs across the north-east of England.

The UK imports around 45 per cent of its CO2 and sources have previously warned of a supply crisis without a domestic bioethanol industry if foreign sources were disrupted.

In June, The Telegraph revealed a leaked memo by industry leaders that said the bioethanol sector was a “critical component” of British food security and energy resilience.

The memo warned: “The closure of Vivergo would damage farm incomes, increase import dependency and undermine the Government’s strategic goals across multiple departments.”

title: Emirates Wants The A380neo - Dj's Aviation
description:
Emirates has championed the usage of the A380-800 for well over a decade, at its peak flying over 100 units in service.
However, with the airline’s business model focusing on a youthful fleet and attempting to renew, there has been much interest in the A380neo.
Details of a prospective A380neo will always remain scarce, this is driven by the reality that the aircraft has not been launched, and interest in it has always been kept on the down low, primarily only from Emirates.
Despite the cost advantages these planes will have on their long-haul network, they still will struggle to complete the job of the A380 because of their smaller stature, but with no dedicated replacement, there must be Emirates’ Interest In The 2010s Emirates’ interest in a prospective Airbus A380neo, while existing only in the last few years, far predates this timeframe, with interest also emerging in 2014.
Emirates, the only airline customer expressing interest in a new model, firmly believed the A380neo, a new engine option, would be the answer, not the plus model.
text:
Emirates has championed the usage of the A380-800 for well over a decade, at its peak flying over 100 units in service.

However, with the airline’s business model focusing on a youthful fleet and attempting to renew, there has been much interest in the A380neo.

But, without the model releasing and comments in recent years, does interest in this new engine option exist before this period, and if so, what did it entail?

What Is The A380neo?

Details of a prospective A380neo will always remain scarce, this is driven by the reality that the aircraft has not been launched, and interest in it has always been kept on the down low, primarily only from Emirates.

But as the three letters on the end of the product suggest, neo, this model would incorporate new engines, like what has been seen with the A320 and A330 families in recent times.

Equipping new engines to an existing platform with other aeronautical improvements can represent a more cost-effective upgrade for an existing platform that may at times lack the efficiency customers require.

If executed, fuel efficiency would’ve improved, and operating costs for the superjumbo would’ve lowered. While not reducing to a level that would’ve resulted in mass adoption, it would’ve at least addressed two of the concerns that prevented the jet from thriving.

While new engines would’ve been the selling point, other improvements would’ve been a priority to bring the model up to speed with newer planes and ensure it would fly for some time longer.

A Love For The A380

Emirates remains the largest operator of the A380-800, having ordered well over 100 units and, at its peak, flying over 120 units, far exceeding any other airline’s commitment to the series.

The airline built its brand around this aircraft, leveraging its high capacity and passenger appeal to help grow its network and Dubai, its home, into a powerhouse for transit travel.

As a result, and with so many Airbus A380’s in its fleet, it isn’t hard to see why there has been so much interest in a possible A380neo, for no adequate replacement exists for the Dubai-based carrier.

Emirates has been forced to look elsewhere, away from the A380 for its future fleet. This has included a heavier reliance on twin-engine aircraft such as the 777X moving forward.

Despite the cost advantages these planes will have on their long-haul network, they still will struggle to complete the job of the A380 because of their smaller stature, but with no dedicated replacement, there must be

Emirates’ Interest In The 2010s

Emirates’ interest in a prospective Airbus A380neo, while existing only in the last few years, far predates this timeframe, with interest also emerging in 2014.

The Dubai-based carrier, at the time led by President Tim Clark, spoke with the Financial Times about the proposition of a new A380 model launching sometime in the future.

At this point, it’s key to remember the A380 was still active, the plane was also still being delivered, and the planemaker had yet to see what would unfold with the program that would ultimately lead to its demise.

Emirates, therefore, was one of the only, if not the only, publicly vocal customers expressing interest in the possibility of a new model being launched, being already the largest operator of the A380-800 and at this point having many more on order.

In the interview, Clark reaffirmed his stance in 2014 that they were interested in the launch of an A380neo, and if the project moved forward, they would buy it in numbers, considering acquiring some 60 to 80 units.

Airbus Studied The Launch

In recent years, discussion from all parties surrounding an A380neo has cooled, driven by airlines shifting away from quad-engined jets more than ever.

Additionally, in the last 11 years since the planemaker first saw significant interest emerge from Emirates, much has occurred with the A380 program, the jet seeing its production life come to an end.

The end of the production life of the A380-800 model didn’t come without attempts to push the jet into markets and extend the production life; however, they ultimately failed, and when Emirates slashed its commitments, the decision to end the superjumbo was confirmed.

Despite this, in 2014, the Chief Commercial Officer at the time, John Leahy, told Aviation Week that internal studies were already underway to help determine whether a future existed for a next-generation A380 release.

With much of the interest in the jet centred around the adoption of new engines and other minor improvements, if released, the planemaker needed to determine whether there would be enough demand to warrant the investment, and what the return would look like.

These studies at the time would’ve seen an estimated six-year process before the jet would have formally launched, in time for the commencement of the new decade, and with hindsight, the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic, which ironically spelled the end of the series.

No Release

Despite Airbus moving ahead with internal studies and conducting its due diligence, a decision to proceed with the launch of an A380neo was ultimately not made.

Airbus would reveal the development study of the A380plus towards the backend of the 2010s in the hopes of showing what possible innovation would give to customers, but this failed.

Emirates, the only airline customer expressing interest in a new model, firmly believed the A380neo, a new engine option, would be the answer, not the plus model. Therefore, when the A380plus was revealed, it unsurprisingly showed little to no interest.

Now, even with the airline’s president, Clark, resurfacing discussions around a re-engine every handful of months, production has closed on the A380-800, and priorities lie elsewhere.

Airbus, alongside engine makers, are busy studying the new era of commercial aircraft travel, and a prospective A380neo would further derail plans and fundamentally take away space and resources from these studies, only to please the likely one interested customer.

Ultimately, Emirates’ long-standing interest did prompt some internal studies in the mid-2010s from the planemaker, but with no action and production ending on the A380, the A380neo’s fate had all but been sealed.

title: UK bioethanol industry on brink of collapse after government refuses support - ChiniMandi
description:
London: Britain’s bioethanol sector is facing collapse after the government ruled out financial aid for producers hit by a trade deal with the United States, reports The Edge Malaysia.
The UK has two main bioethanol plants, Associated British Foods’ Vivergo facility and Ensus, owned by Germany’s Südzucker Group, both located in northern England.
AB Foods warned in June it would shut the Vivergo plant by September without government support.
Industry groups say the trade deal, combined with existing rules that give U.S. producers an edge, has made operations unviable.
Bioethanol, made from crops like wheat, is used to reduce emissions in petrol and as a feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel.
text:
London: Britain’s bioethanol sector is facing collapse after the government ruled out financial aid for producers hit by a trade deal with the United States, reports The Edge Malaysia.

A government spokesperson said on Friday, “We have taken the difficult decision not to offer direct funding as it would not provide value for taxpayers or solve the industry’s long-term problems.”

Under the agreement signed by former Prime Minister Theresa May, the UK cut its 19% tariffs on U.S. ethanol to zero within a quota of 1.4 billion litres — equal to the size of the entire British ethanol market.

The UK has two main bioethanol plants, Associated British Foods’ Vivergo facility and Ensus, owned by Germany’s Südzucker Group, both located in northern England. Together, they make up almost all of the country’s production capacity.

AB Foods warned in June it would shut the Vivergo plant by September without government support. Ensus has also said its plant is at risk of closure.

A spokesperson for AB Foods said it was “deeply regrettable that the government has chosen not to support a key national asset.” Ensus did not immediately comment.

Industry groups say the trade deal, combined with existing rules that give U.S. producers an edge, has made operations unviable. The sector directly supports thousands of jobs in the UK.

Bioethanol, made from crops like wheat, is used to reduce emissions in petrol and as a feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel.

title: Petrolimex Aviation và Vietjet Air tiên phong xanh hoá bầu trời Việt
description:
Đây là hành động cụ thể, đặt nền móng cho việc hình thành chuỗi cung ứng SAF tại Việt Nam.
Có thể nói, hai mốc sự kiện trên là minh chứng rõ ràng cho lộ trình hành động mà Petrolimex Aviation đã và đang triển khai.
Trong đó có sự góp mặt từ những ngày đầu của Petrolimex Aviation.
Petrolimex Aviation đã đạt ra mục tiêu phủ xanh bầu trời Việt Nam sẽ không chỉ là một khẩu hiệu truyền thông.
Không dừng lại ở việc giảm phát thải, đó còn là khát vọng vươn tầm vị thế Việt Nam trên bản đồ hàng không thế giới.
text:
Chiến lược xanh và cam kết Net Zero 2050

Thực hiện cam kết của Việt Nam tại Hội nghị COP26 về phát thải ròng bằng 0 vào năm 2050, ngành hàng không Việt Nam đã đặt ra yêu cầu phải cắt giảm phát thải carbon và metan của ngành hàng không Việt Nam thông qua việc chuyển đổi năng lượng, đặc biệt là chuyển đổi từ nhiên liệu hoá thạch sang nhiên liệu bền vững Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).

Việc thực hiện cam kết tại Hội nghị COP26 cũng phù hợp với chiến lược phát triển năng lượng xanh, sạch, thân thiện với môi trường của Tập đoàn Xăng dầu Việt Nam.

Để thực hiện chủ trương này, SAF được xem là giải pháp khả thi nhất hiện nay khi các công nghệ như máy bay điện, hoặc hydro còn ở giai đoạn thử nghiệm.

Petrolimex Aviation đã triển khai nhập khẩu, kiểm soát chất lượng, lưu trữ và xuất bán SAF theo đúng các quy định tại tiêu chuẩn ASTM D7566, DEF STAN 91-091 và AFQRJOS Checklist phiên bản hiện hành; các tiêu chuẩn của Hiệp hội Vận tải Hàng không Quốc tế (IATA), Tổ chức kiểm tra chung (JIG) và Bộ Giao thông vận tải (nay là Bộ Xây dựng).

Đánh dấu cho chiến lược “xanh hóa” này là sự kiện Petrolimex Aviation thực hiện thành công việc tra nạp nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững - Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) cho 2 chuyến bay số hiệu VJ081 và VJ860 của Hãng hàng không Vietjet (Vietjet Air) xuất phát từ TP Hồ Chí Minh (Việt Nam) đi Melbourne (Australia) và Incheon (Hàn Quốc) ngày 17/10/2024.

Đây là hành động cụ thể, đặt nền móng cho việc hình thành chuỗi cung ứng SAF tại Việt Nam.

Sự kiện này cũng đánh dấu lần đầu tiên SAF được sử dụng cho các chuyến bay khởi hành từ Việt Nam, thể hiện nỗ lực, quyết tâm của Petrolimex Aviation trong việc phát triển sản phẩm xanh - sạch, sẵn sàng cung cấp SAF đáp ứng nhu cầu của các hãng hàng không trong nước và quốc tế.

Không dừng lại ở đó, ngày 15/8, Petrolimex Aviation tiếp tục có bước tiến chiến lược, đó là ký kết thỏa thuận cung cấp 1.200 m³ (1.200.000 lít) SAF đầu tiên được pha trộn tại Việt Nam cho các chuyến bay nội địa của Vietjet, đồng thời hợp tác với AEG FUEL nhằm hỗ trợ thương mại hóa SAF tại Việt Nam cho các hãng hàng không quốc tế trong tương lai.

Đây là dấu mốc mở ra khả năng sản xuất - pha trộn - phân phối SAF ngay trong nước, giảm phụ thuộc nhập khẩu và thúc đẩy ngành hàng không Việt Nam tiến gần hơn đến mục tiêu giảm phát thải ròng.

Nói về ý nghĩa của sự kiện này, ông Uông Việt Dũng - Cục trưởng Cục Hàng không Việt Nam cho biết, việc ra mắt sản phẩm SAF không chỉ có ý nghĩa về mặt thương mại, mà còn mang ý nghĩa chiến lược lâu dài, tạo tiền đề xây dựng chuỗi cung ứng SAF bền vững trong nước; góp phần đáp ứng các yêu cầu bắt buộc của thị trường quốc tế, đặc biệt là RefuelEU Aviation của Liên minh châu Âu và CORSIA của ICAO; khuyến khích hợp tác giữa các hãng hàng không, đơn vị cung cấp nhiên liệu, cơ quan quản lý và các tổ chức tài chính nhằm mở rộng quy mô sử dụng SAF tại Việt Nam.

Còn ông Phạm Văn Thanh - Chủ tịch Hội đồng quản trị Tập đoàn Xăng dầu Việt Nam thì cho rằng, ngoài việc công bố sản phẩm SAF, Công ty CP Nhiên liệu bay Petrolimex Aviation sẽ ký kết các biên bản ghi nhớ hợp tác chiến lược với hai đối tác lớn là Vietjet Air và AEG (Associated Energy Group).

“Những thỏa thuận này khẳng định quyết tâm của Petrolimex trong việc đóng góp thiết thực vào việc giảm phát thải và nâng cao vị thế quốc gia trên bản đồ năng lượng xanh toàn cầu”, ông Thanh nói.

Tổng giám đốc Petrolimex Aviation Nguyễn Văn Học cho biết, trong quá trình triển khai, Petrolimex Aviation đã nhận được sự hỗ trợ quý báu của các cơ quan quản lý nhà nước như: Cục Hàng không Việt Nam, Cục Quản lý và Phát triển Thị trường trong nước - Bộ Công thương, Cục Hải quan trong việc cấp phép, hoàn thiện tiêu chuẩn và chính sách, tạo điều kiện thuận lợi cho công tác triển khai sản phẩm SAF.

Nói về sự hợp tác giữa Công ty Petrolimex Aviation (PA) và Công ty cổ phần Hàng không Vietjet (VJC) và Công ty AEG Fuels, Tổng giám đốc Nguyễn Văn Học cho biết, VJC và PA đã cùng đồng hành trong nhiều năm qua, từ giai đoạn hình thành, phát triển cho đến vượt qua thử thách của đại dịch, không chỉ trên phương diện kinh doanh, mà còn ở mục tiêu chung là phát triển bền vững của ngành hàng không Việt Nam.

“Tháng 10/2024, PA và VJC hai bên đã ghi dấu mốc lịch sử khi thực hiện 2 chuyến bay sử dụng SAF đầu tiên tại Việt Nam do PA tra nạp.

Tiếp nối thành công đó, ngày 15/8, Công ty PA và Công ty CP Hàng không Vietjet sẽ triển khai tra nạp toàn bộ 1.200.000 lít SAF đầu tiên được pha trộn tại Việt Nam cho các chuyến bay nội địa của Vietjet - tương đương lượng nhiên liệu tra nạp cho 200 chuyến, sẽ bay từ sân bay Tân Sơn Nhất tới khắp các tỉnh thành Việt Nam, điều này sẽ góp phần “xanh hóa” bầu trời.

Đây là hành động cụ thể biến cam kết thành hiện thực, góp phần chắp cánh cho những chuyến bay xanh, an toàn và bền vững”, ông Học nói.

Với đối với đối tác AEG FUELS, đại diện PA cho biết, đây cũng là đối tác thương mại lâu năm của PA tại thị trường Việt Nam và Quốc tế từ năm 2011 đến này. “Với với kinh nghiệm triển khai SAF và mạng lưới khách hàng là các các hãng hàng không toàn cầu, PA tin tưởng rằng AEG FUELS sẽ giúp kết nối thị trường Việt Nam với xu thế sử dụng SAF của thế giới, mở ra những cơ hội hợp tác sâu rộng trong tương lai”, ông Học chia sẻ.

Có thể nói, hai mốc sự kiện trên là minh chứng rõ ràng cho lộ trình hành động mà Petrolimex Aviation đã và đang triển khai. Phát triển bền vững nhưng dám gánh vác trên vai trách nhiệm quốc gia trước cộng đồng quốc tế.

Khát vọng phủ xanh bầu trời Việt của Petrolimex Aviation

Trong bối cảnh hiện nay, Việt Nam đang khẩn trương xây dựng kế hoạch quốc gia về sản xuất SAF và chuẩn bị tham gia Chương trình bù đắp và giảm thiểu carbon cho hàng không quốc tế (CORSIA) của ICAO.

Phó Thủ tướng Chính phủ Trần Hồng Hà cũng đã chỉ đạo Cục Hàng không Việt Nam chuẩn bị đề xuất chi tiết, đồng thời yêu cầu các nhà sản xuất và lọc dầu trong nước vạch ra kế hoạch cụ thể cho sản xuất SAF.

Bộ Tài chính và Bộ Ngoại giao cũng được giao nhiệm vụ xem xét các lựa chọn áp phí đối với các chuyến bay quốc tế khởi hành từ Việt Nam, cũng như các ưu đãi thuế và hỗ trợ tài chính để thúc đẩy sản xuất SAF trong nước.

Ngay cả các nhà sản xuất máy bay như Airbus cũng cam kết các dòng máy bay của họ, như A330neo và A321neo, hiện có thể vận hành với tối đa 50% SAF, với mục tiêu tăng lên 100% khả năng sử dụng SAF vào năm 2030.

Tuy nhiên, hiện chi phí sản xuất SAF cao hơn nhiên liệu truyền thống và nguồn cung toàn cầu còn hạn chế dù thị trường đang tăng trưởng nhanh.

Theo dự báo của ResourceWise, giá trị thị trường SAF có thể đạt 3,92 tỷ USD vào năm 2028, điều này mở ra cơ hội lớn cho những doanh nghiệp tiên phong. Trong đó có sự góp mặt từ những ngày đầu của Petrolimex Aviation.

Từ nhận thức sâu sắc rằng, mỗi chuyến bay sẽ không chỉ mang sứ mệnh vận chuyển hành khách, hàng hóa..., mà còn mang theo trách nhiệm phủ xanh bầu trời và bảo vệ một tương lai xanh cho các thế hệ mai sau.

Petrolimex Aviation đã đạt ra mục tiêu phủ xanh bầu trời Việt Nam sẽ không chỉ là một khẩu hiệu truyền thông.

Petrolimex Aviation đặt mục tiêu đến năm 2050 sẽ đồng hành cùng ngành hàng không Việt Nam loại bỏ hoàn toàn phát thải ròng CO₂, thông qua việc: Tăng tỷ trọng SAF trong tổng lượng nhiên liệu cung ứng hàng năm, tiến tới thương mại hóa và sử dụng rộng rãi trên cả các đường bay quốc tế và nội địa; Phát triển chuỗi cung ứng SAF nội địa - từ nghiên cứu nguyên liệu tái tạo, hợp tác sản xuất - pha trộn, đến hệ thống phân phối và tra nạp đồng bộ tại các sân bay lớn; Hợp tác toàn cầu với các hãng hàng không, nhà sản xuất và tổ chức quốc tế nhằm cập nhật công nghệ, giảm chi phí sản xuất SAF và mở rộng quy mô ứng dụng.

Không dừng lại ở việc giảm phát thải, đó còn là khát vọng vươn tầm vị thế Việt Nam trên bản đồ hàng không thế giới. Biến Việt Nam thành trung tâm cung cấp nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững trong khu vực, nơi mà mỗi chuyến bay cất cánh từ mảnh đất hình chữ S sẽ mang theo thông điệp mạnh mẽ: “Việt Nam cam kết và hành động vì một hành tinh xanh”.

title: Airbus Is About to Eclipse a Record That Boeing Held for Decades - Yahoo Finance
description:
In 1981, the year Airbus SE announced it would build a new single-aisle jetliner to take on Boeing Co., the 737 ruled the roost.
By 1988, when Airbus began producing its upstart A320, Boeing had built a formidable lead by delivering some 1,500 of its cigar-shaped best-seller.
But the 737 stubbornly remained the most-delivered commercial aircraft of all time.
The European planemaker, an assemblage of aerospace manufacturers formed in 1970 with backing from European governments, didn’t yet offer a full aircraft lineup.
Those aircraft are by far the most widely flown category in commercial aviation, typically connecting city pairs on shorter routes.
text:
In 1981, the year Airbus SE announced it would build a new single-aisle jetliner to take on Boeing Co., the 737 ruled the roost.

The US-made narrowbody, already in use for more than a decade, had reshaped the airline industry by making shorter routes cheaper and more profitable to operate. By 1988, when Airbus began producing its upstart A320, Boeing had built a formidable lead by delivering some 1,500 of its cigar-shaped best-seller.

Most Read from Bloomberg

The US-Canadian Road Safety Gap Is Getting Wider

Festivals and Parades Are Canceled Amid US Immigration Anxiety

A Photographer’s Pipe Dream: Capturing New York’s Vast Water System

Five Years After Black Lives Matter, Brussels’ Colonial Statues Remain

Princeton Plans New Budget Cuts as Pressure From Trump Builds

It’s taken the better part of four decades, but Airbus has finally caught up: The A320 series is poised to overtake its US competitor as the most-delivered commercial airliner in history, according to aviation consultancy Cirium. As of early August, Airbus had winnowed the gap to just 20 units, with 12,155 lifetime A320-family shipments, according to the data. That difference is likely to disappear as soon as next month.

“Did anyone back then expect it could become number one – and on such high production volumes?” Max Kingsley-Jones, head of advisory at Cirium Ascend, wrote of the A320 in a recent social-media post. “I certainly didn’t, and nor probably did Airbus.”

The A320’s success mirrors the European planemaker’s decades-long rise from fledgling planemaker to serious contender, and finally Boeing’s better. By the early 2000s, annual deliveries of the A320 and its derivatives had surpassed the 737 family; total orders eclipsed the Boeing jet in 2019. But the 737 stubbornly remained the most-delivered commercial aircraft of all time.

At the outset, Airbus faced an uphill battle. The European planemaker, an assemblage of aerospace manufacturers formed in 1970 with backing from European governments, didn’t yet offer a full aircraft lineup. Infighting hindered everything from product planning to manufacturing, and leadership decisions had to finely balance French and German commercial and political interests.

Yet it was clear even then that Airbus needed a presence in the narrowbody segment to firmly establish itself as Boeing’s top rival. Those aircraft are by far the most widely flown category in commercial aviation, typically connecting city pairs on shorter routes.

Higher fuel costs and the deregulation of the US aviation industry in the late 1970s had given the European planemaker an opening with American airline executives, who clamored for an all-new single-aisle, according to a history of Airbus written by journalist Nicola Clark.

Australia’s mining industry remains a cornerstone of the national economy, playing a critical role both regionally and globally. Not only does this place Australia at the forefront among leading mining nations, but it also demonstrates a substantial commitment to responsible and innovative regulation, reflecting both technological advancements and lessons learned from past incidents.

In this comprehensive guide, we unveil the key updates in Australia mining safety regulations 2025, focusing on vital aspects such as worker protection, the integration of state-of-the-art technologies, sustainability, and regulatory oversight. This resource is intended to support industry professionals, mine operators, workers, and all stakeholders in ensuring compliance, promoting best practices, and enhancing the future of mining in Australia.

Summary: Enhancing Worker Protection and Sustainable Practices

With the importance of mining in the Australian economy, ensuring workforce safety and sustainability isn’t merely an obligation—it’s a necessity. The 2025 updates to the australia mining safety regulations introduce a comprehensive regulatory framework focused on proactive risk management, worker health, advanced technology deployment, and the integration of sustainable practices. Such an approach amplifies the level of protection afforded to all stakeholders within mines and underlines Australia’s path toward responsible, safe, and prosperous mining activities for years to come.

Regulatory Framework and Oversight in Australia Mining Safety Regulations 2025

The foundational legal architecture guiding mining safety in Australia is rooted in the Work Health and Safety (Mines) Act 2020 and its subsequent amendments updated through 2025. These regulations are meticulously administered at both state and territory levels, with major stakeholders including the Department of Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety (DMIRS) in Western Australia and Resources Safety & Health Queensland.

The 2025 regulatory landscape sees:

Increased harmonization of safety standards across Australia’s diverse geographies—creating a uniform, national standard.

Formalized collaboration between state and territory authorities—enabling consistency in oversight, compliance, and worker protection protocols throughout all mines in the nation.

Dynamic adaptation of regulations to suit technological progress and sustainable practices.

Australia’s approach remains responsive, adaptive, and focused on the paramount importance of safety within this critical sector. This harmonized framework ensures that lessons from past incidents are reflected in regulatory requirements, propelling improvements in both surface and underground operations.

“Worker safety training hours in Australian mines will increase by 30% under the 2025 regulatory updates.”

The 2025 revisions bring a blend of robust standards, innovative technologies, and sustainable practices, strengthening Australia’s global leadership in mining safety. Below, we cover the most significant regulatory shifts:

1. Enhanced Risk Management Protocols

Proactive Risk Assessments: Operators are mandated to conduct thorough, frequent risk assessments throughout all mining phases, leveraging real-time data to dynamically adapt and ensure the safety of the workforce.

AI & IoT Integration: Regulations now require mines to deploy advanced hazard identification systems, incorporating IoT sensors and AI-powered analytics. These monitor:

Gas concentrations

Seismic activity

Ventilation quality

Environmental conditions across both surface and underground operations

These technologies trigger automated alerts to miners and control centers, enabling immediate responses and preventing escalation of hazardous situations.

Such integration of advanced systems ensures that mines remain responsive to conditions in real time, significantly reducing the inherent risks traditional mining operations pose. Continuous monitoring now forms the backbone of every responsible mining operation.

2. Mental Health and Wellbeing in Mining: Regulatory Developments

Mental Health Management Plans now must be tailored specifically to the mining sector. Employers are required to:

Offer access to mental health support services.

Provide comprehensive training for identifying mental distress among workers.

Promote open dialogue and peer support as part of organizational culture.

These regulations reflect a broadened understanding of workplace safety, recognizing that psychological wellbeing stands on equal footing with traditional physical hazard management.

By integrating these updated protocols, Australia is not only promoting a healthier workforce but enhancing worker protection and overall mine productivity.

3. Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Standards for 2025

Smart Helmets with AR Displays: Operators must now supply cutting-edge helmets equipped with AR—offering visual hazard warnings, real-time alerts, and communication capabilities, thus significantly enhancing safety for miners.

Advanced Respirators: Regulations require improved respirators designed for greater comfort and prolonged use, featuring enhanced filtration and ergonomic design to support miners in even the harshest environments.

PPE must now meet not only durability requirements but also smart functionality support for real-time hazard identification and worker welfare.

With these enhanced standards, PPE forms a foundational pillar in the comprehensive safety protocols for 2025.

For those interested in integrating carbon footprinting and environmental impact monitoring into mining safety compliance and sustainability plans, discover how Farmonaut’s Carbon Footprinting solution can provide actionable, satellite-driven data insights for your operations.

4. Automation and Remote Operations Safety

Fail-safe Mechanisms: Automated and remotely operated mining equipment must now include advanced safety mechanisms, ensuring that in the event of a malfunction, human workers are not placed at increased risk.

Cybersecurity Protocols: Recognizing the vulnerabilities that come with automation, 2025 regulations require strict cybersecurity standards to prevent hostile cyber-intrusions that could compromise safe mine operations.

Operators and miners involved with remote equipment are required to undergo regular training on these new systems for maximum risk mitigation.

This focus on automation and remote safety underscores the regulatory ambition to stay ahead of technology, not merely reacting to risks but anticipating and preventing them.

Managing a fleet of advanced mining machinery? Farmonaut’s Fleet Management tools offer real-time, satellite-aided monitoring—enhancing safety, optimizing logistics, and ensuring regulatory compliance in your mining operations.

5. Emergency Preparedness and Response Protocols

Multi-Agency Drills & VR Simulation: 2025 regulations mandate regular drills involving mine staff, emergency responders, and medical teams. These exercises increasingly employ virtual reality (VR) scenarios—enabling realistic practice for events such as underground fires or structural collapses.

Communication Infrastructure: Updated requirements demand faster, more reliable, and disaster-resilient communication systems throughout all site operations, both at surface and underground levels.

Known weaknesses identified from past incidents have fueled more robust emergency planning, ensuring that Australia remains safer and more responsive under all circumstances.

By standardizing these protocols and integrating the latest in safety technology, australia mining safety regulations 2025 ensure comprehensive protection for all mine workers.

Sustainability and Worker Safety Integration in Mining Regulations 2025

Environmental responsibility now lies at the heart of the australia mining safety regulations 2025. Today’s regulations expand the definition of safety to include sustainable practices, ensuring worker health and ecosystem integrity move forward together.

Cleaner Mining Technologies: Mines are regulated to reduce dust and noise pollution, directly benefiting worker health and the surrounding environment.

Rehabilitation and Closure Safety: Rehabilitation plans now must address not only environmental restoration but also the safety of employees involved in closure and land rehabilitation activities.

Resource Traceability: New mandates encourage keeping track of mining outputs and byproducts through traceability frameworks for responsible stewardship and regulatory transparency.

Through integrating sustainability and safety regulations, mines remain both productive and respectful of Australia’s unique and diverse geographies.

Industry Collaboration and Continuous Improvement

To actualize the spirit of australia mining safety regulations 2025, continuous improvement is paramount. Building a robust safety and sustainability culture in mining requires coordinated effort across stakeholders, including governmental authorities, industry groups, unions, research institutions, and individual operators.

Continuous Professional Development: All mine workers and operators participate in ongoing skill-building, regulatory training, and technology awareness.

Data Sharing & Analytics: Mining operations are encouraged to report risk patterns, incidents, and safety innovations—aiding in benchmarking and industry-wide improvement.

Open Communication: The regulations now emphasize transparent, two-way communication between operators and regulatory authorities, ensuring that feedback from frontline workers informs the evolution of compliance requirements.

The combination of industry collaboration and regulatory oversight ensures not just compliance, but genuine progress in safety and sustainability standards among mines across Australia.

As regulatory expectations in Australia’s mining sector rise in complexity and sophistication, operators and stakeholders need comprehensive technological support to ensure compliance, uphold safety, and drive environmental stewardship. FAQ: Australia Mining Safety Regulations 2025

What are the key changes in the australia mining safety regulations 2025?

Major updates include mandatory use of smart PPE, AI-based risk assessments, enhanced mental health protocols, stricter automation safety standards, VR-based emergency drills, real-time environmental monitoring, and 100% sustainable waste management at all major mine sites.

Who administers these regulations in Australia?

Regulations are implemented at both state and territory levels by entities like the DMIRS in Western Australia and Resources Safety & Health Queensland, under a harmonized national framework.

How often must risk assessments be conducted under the 2025 updates?

All mines are required to conduct dynamic, continuous risk assessments, leveraging IoT sensors, AI analytics, and real-time reporting to detect and mitigate hazards as soon as they arise.

Is worker mental health management now a compliance requirement?

Yes, mental health and wellbeing are now formally part of regulatory compliance, requiring dedicated management plans, ongoing worker support, and comprehensive training.

What technology is now mandated for worker safety in mines?

Smart AR helmets, advanced respirators, fail-safe mechanisms on automated equipment, continuous AI-based hazard monitoring, VR-based drills, and secure communication infrastructure are among the new technology requirements.

How do updated regulations enhance sustainability?

Mines must track and report carbon footprints, manage waste sustainably, and employ advanced remediation and land recovery strategies, ensuring environmental and worker safety goals are met together.

How can technology platforms like Farmonaut help ensure compliance and boost sustainability?

Farmonaut provides the required real-time satellite monitoring, AI advisories, fleet/resource optimization, carbon tracking, and traceability tools to meet and exceed australia mining safety regulations 2025.

Conclusion

The transformation detailed in australia mining safety regulations 2025 marks a defining moment for the industry—combining stringent worker protection, mental health considerations, cutting-edge technology, and eco-friendly practices into a single, robust regulatory framework. This ensures Australia remains a world leader among mining nations, renowned for promoting a culture of safety, responsibility, and continuous improvement.

Guided by harmonized oversight, advanced technology, and comprehensive management protocols, all stakeholders—from mine operators to individual workers—benefit from a safer workplace and a cleaner environment. Technology providers like Farmonaut are actively enabling industry players to leverage satellite insight, blockchain transparency, and smart resource management—driving operational excellence and compliance across the mining industry.

title: DHL Express and Neste Sign Landmark Deal for Sustainable Aviation Fuel in Singapore
description:
DHL Express and Neste have strengthened their collaboration with a new agreement for the supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Singapore.
The deal, which is one of the largest in Asia for the air cargo sector, will see Neste supply 9.5 million liters (7,400 metric tons) of its Neste MY Sustainable Aviation Fuel to DHL Express over a one-year period, beginning in July 2025.
By using Neste’s SAF, which is blended with conventional jet fuel, DHL aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by around 80% over the fuel’s lifecycle.
Commitment to Sustainable Logistics Christopher Ong, Managing Director for DHL Express Singapore, called the partnership a significant milestone for the company’s emission reduction efforts and a way to provide more sustainable shipping options to customers.
As a major global user of SAF, DHL Express has been a leader in driving voluntary demand for the fuel.
text:
DHL Express and Neste have strengthened their collaboration with a new agreement for the supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Singapore. The deal, which is one of the largest in Asia for the air cargo sector, will see Neste supply 9.5 million liters (7,400 metric tons) of its Neste MY Sustainable Aviation Fuel to DHL Express over a one-year period, beginning in July 2025. This marks DHL’s first direct procurement of SAF for flights departing from Singapore Changi Airport.

Fueling International Flights from Singapore

The SAF, produced at Neste’s refinery in Singapore, will be used to power about 35 to 40% of the overall fuel needs for DHL Express’ five Boeing 777 freighters. These aircraft are based at the South Asia Hub at Singapore Changi Airport and operate 12 intercontinental flights per week, connecting Singapore to destinations in Asia and the Americas. By using Neste’s SAF, which is blended with conventional jet fuel, DHL aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by around 80% over the fuel’s lifecycle.

Commitment to Sustainable Logistics

Christopher Ong, Managing Director for DHL Express Singapore, called the partnership a significant milestone for the company’s emission reduction efforts and a way to provide more sustainable shipping options to customers. The agreement will also contribute to Singapore’s national target of 1% SAF usage for all passenger and cargo flights from 2026 onwards.

As a major global user of SAF, DHL Express has been a leader in driving voluntary demand for the fuel. The company’s GoGreen Plus service allows customers to reduce their carbon emissions through the use of SAF, with the environmental benefits being allocated through a ‘book & claim’ approach.

outlet: Indian PSU | Public Sector Undertaking News
title: Why Workers Still Protest? Asks veteran Trade Union Leader C. Srikumar - Indian PSU
description:
But beneath the celebrations lies a bitter truth — while the government basks in the glory of freedom, workers, farmers, and their unions are still forced to fight for their basic rights.
After independence, workers were the backbone of nation-building — expanding railways, setting up defence industries, driving irrigation projects, building public sector enterprises, and ensuring the nationalisation of banks and insurance.
Public sector jewels are being sold off.
Reservation for marginalised communities exists only in the public sector — and yet, this very sector is being dismantled.
Bank employees fight privatisation, insurance workers fight for wage revision, municipal conservancy workers fight for regularisation, ordnance factory employees fight corporatisation, and government staff demand the restoration of the Old Pension Scheme.
text:
OPINION PIECE

India marked its 79th Independence Day with tricolours flying high, patriotic songs, and the national anthem echoing across the country. But beneath the celebrations lies a bitter truth — while the government basks in the glory of freedom, workers, farmers, and their unions are still forced to fight for their basic rights.

Just a month ago, on July 9, lakhs of workers participated in a one-day nationwide general strike. The question is unavoidable: why, after nearly eight decades of independence, do we still have to take to the streets for justice?

Let history not be forgotten. During the freedom struggle, it was the working class and trade unions — particularly the AITUC — that stood shoulder to shoulder with the national movement, winning landmark rights like the Trade Union Act of 1926 even under colonial rule. After independence, workers were the backbone of nation-building — expanding railways, setting up defence industries, driving irrigation projects, building public sector enterprises, and ensuring the nationalisation of banks and insurance.

But over the last two decades, successive governments have betrayed this legacy. Under the banner of “ease of doing business” and corporate-friendly reforms, permanent jobs have been killed off, replaced with insecure contract and fixed-term work. Public sector jewels are being sold off. Even core sectors — defence, education, healthcare, electricity, banking, insurance — are not spared. Social security is being shredded. In today’s India, job security is a relic, and dignity of labour is under assault.

Unemployment and underemployment plague our youth. In the Central Government alone, over 15 lakh posts lie vacant; in PSUs and banks, another 5–10 lakh. Reservation for marginalised communities exists only in the public sector — and yet, this very sector is being dismantled. Bank employees fight privatisation, insurance workers fight for wage revision, municipal conservancy workers fight for regularisation, ordnance factory employees fight corporatisation, and government staff demand the restoration of the Old Pension Scheme.

Worse still, the government refuses to talk. The Indian Labour Conference — the country’s highest tripartite forum — has not been convened. The Joint Consultative Machinery for government employees is paralysed. This is not governance; this is contempt.

India today is an economic power, but let us be clear: it is the sweat of its workers and farmers that made this possible. A country that ignores them is not on the road to development — it is on the road to injustice. As we approach the 80th year of independence, the government must shed its arrogance, return to dialogue, and respect the principles of socialism and secularism enshrined in our Constitution.

Freedom without justice for workers is not true freedom, he concludes.

title: Airbus Is About to Eclipse a Record That Boeing Held for Decades - Bloomberg
description:
In 1981, the year Airbus SE announced it would build a new single-aisle jetliner to take on Boeing Co., the 737 ruled the roost.
The US-made narrowbody, already in use for more than a decade, had reshaped the airline industry by making shorter routes cheaper and more profitable to operate.
By 1988, when Airbus began producing its upstart A320, Boeing had built a formidable lead by delivering some 1,500 of its cigar-shaped best-seller.
text:

title: Vietnam successfully produces sustainable aviation fuel | SGGP English Edition
description:
According to Mr. Pham Van Thanh, Chairman of the Board of Directors at Petrolimex, the group has proactively conducted research and mastered the technology for blending sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) at Nha Be Oil Terminal.
This achievement underscores Petrolimex’s strong commitment to green transition efforts, aligning with the Government, airlines, and society in the pursuit of sustainable development.
Speaking at the launching ceremony, Mr. Uong Viet Dung, Director of the Civil Aviation Authority of Vietnam, praised Petrolimex for taking the lead in researching, blending, and supplying sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
He noted that the launch of SAF is not only commercially significant but also lays the foundation for developing a sustainable domestic SAF supply chain that meets international market demands.
Experts note that sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) shares similar chemical properties with conventional jet fuel (Jet A-1), allowing it to be processed through the same supply chain without the need for changes to existing infrastructure or aircraft engines.
text:
According to Mr. Pham Van Thanh, Chairman of the Board of Directors at Petrolimex, the group has proactively conducted research and mastered the technology for blending sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) at Nha Be Oil Terminal. This achievement underscores Petrolimex’s strong commitment to green transition efforts, aligning with the Government, airlines, and society in the pursuit of sustainable development.

Speaking at the launching ceremony, Mr. Uong Viet Dung, Director of the Civil Aviation Authority of Vietnam, praised Petrolimex for taking the lead in researching, blending, and supplying sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). He noted that the launch of SAF is not only commercially significant but also lays the foundation for developing a sustainable domestic SAF supply chain that meets international market demands.

Experts note that sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) shares similar chemical properties with conventional jet fuel (Jet A-1), allowing it to be processed through the same supply chain without the need for changes to existing infrastructure or aircraft engines. The use of SAF can reduce carbon emissions by up to 80 percent compared to traditional jet fuel, a significant advancement in the effort to decarbonize the aviation sector, which is responsible for nearly 5 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions.

By Thi Hong – Translated by Kim Khanh

title: Cairo affirms full support for ICAO's new strategic plan - Egyptian Gazette
description:
By Mohamed Attia Civil Aviation Minister Samah el-Hefny emphasised Egypt’s support for the new strategic plan of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).
El-Hefny emphasised that the participation of the Ministry of Civil Aviation reflects its continuous commitment to enhancing co-operation with ICAO and the Member States.
The meeting addressed the main pillars of ICAO’s new strategic plan (2026–2050), most notably the modernisation of the air navigation system, economic regulation, and human resource development.
The attendees also discussed developments in air transport and regional connectivity, reviewed the outcomes of the World Air Cargo Summit, and considered the recommendations of the ICAO Air Services Negotiation Events (ICAN).
He also highlighted the role of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) in unifying visions among Member States and supporting joint efforts to advance the global aviation industry.
text:
By Mohamed Attia

Civil Aviation Minister Samah el-Hefny emphasised Egypt’s support for the new strategic plan of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).

The minister also asserted that the Ministry places the improvement of personnel and the modernisation of technical infrastructure at the top of its priorities, in alignment with the highest international standards.

This came during el-Hefny’s participation in the 13th Meeting of Civil Aviation Authority Officials for the North America, Central America and Caribbean Region (NACC/DCA/13), organised by the ICAO in Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic.

The event witnessed broad participation from chairpersons and representatives of civil aviation authorities in the Member States, as well as heads of relevant regional and international organisations.

El-Hefny emphasised that the participation of the Ministry of Civil Aviation reflects its continuous commitment to enhancing co-operation with ICAO and the Member States.

He also highlighted the importance of such meetings for exchanging expertise and coordinating policies to address the sector’s challenges.

The minister stated that Egypt pays great attention to regional integration and mutual technical co-operation, as well as aligning its national legislation with international requirements.

This is within the framework of balancing market liberalisation with the protection of developing countries’ interests.

The meeting addressed the main pillars of ICAO’s new strategic plan (2026–2050), most notably the modernisation of the air navigation system, economic regulation, and human resource development.

The attendees also discussed developments in air transport and regional connectivity, reviewed the outcomes of the World Air Cargo Summit, and considered the recommendations of the ICAO Air Services Negotiation Events (ICAN).

On the sidelines of the meeting, Minister el-Hefny participated in the 12th Session of the Steering Committee of the Multiregional Assistance Programme (MCAAP – RLA/09/801 PSC/12), which addressed ways to enhance the capabilities of civil aviation authorities in the fields of safety and security, as well as in training, air transport, and compliance with international standards.

The committee also reviewed the tangible progress in implementing environmental initiatives adopted by ICAO, including the Sustainable Aviation Fuel programme (ACT-SAF), the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA), as well as national action plans to reduce emissions.

This comes within the global trend towards a more sustainable aviation sector.

The minister concluded his participation by emphasising Egypt’s continued support for the sustainable development of the aviation sector, both regionally and internationally, through active participation in ICAO’s environmental and technical initiatives, and by enhancing institutional and operational performance.

He also highlighted the role of the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) in unifying visions among Member States and supporting joint efforts to advance the global aviation industry.

title: Which company became the first in India to secure the ISCC CORSIA certification for ... - GKToday
description:
Which company became the first in India to secure the ISCC CORSIA certification for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF)?
Answer: Indian Oil Corporation Ltd. (Indian Oil) Notes: Indian Oil Corporation Ltd. (Indian Oil) became the first company in India to secure International Sustainability & Carbon Certification (ISCC) CORSIA for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) at its Panipat Refinery.
The certification is mandatory for commercial SAF production and aligns India with global aviation fuel standards.
Certificate was handed over by Cotecna to Indian Oil Chairman A.S. Sahney in New Delhi.
ISCC CORSIA, developed under Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) of International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), ensures sustainability and lifecycle carbon standards.
text:
Q. Which company became the first in India to secure the ISCC CORSIA certification for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF)?

Answer: Indian Oil Corporation Ltd. (Indian Oil)

Notes: Indian Oil Corporation Ltd. (Indian Oil) became the first company in India to secure International Sustainability & Carbon Certification (ISCC) CORSIA for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) at its Panipat Refinery. The certification is mandatory for commercial SAF production and aligns India with global aviation fuel standards. Certificate was handed over by Cotecna to Indian Oil Chairman A.S. Sahney in New Delhi. ISCC CORSIA, developed under Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) of International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), ensures sustainability and lifecycle carbon standards.

title: Nebraska's corn producers could find a new market in sustainable aviation fuel - KMTV
description:
WATCH KATRINA'S STORY BELOW Nebraska's corn industry could find new market in sustainable aviation fuel Rep. Mike Flood convened a conference at the museum on Friday.
The goal, he said, was to help Nebraska farmers learn about potential opportunities with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
Sustainable aviation fuel is essentially ethanol for aviation.
While some see opportunities to make money, not everyone in agriculture agrees that sustainable aviation fuel is beneficial.
"What they're talking about, in terms of sustainable aviation fuel, is a fairy tale," said Trent Loos, rancher and political activist.
text:
ASHLAND, Neb. (KMTV) — The SAC Museum in Ashland was the backdrop for a discussion about the future of aviation and how Nebraska farmers might play a key role in it.

WATCH KATRINA'S STORY BELOW

Nebraska's corn industry could find new market in sustainable aviation fuel

Rep. Mike Flood convened a conference at the museum on Friday. The goal, he said, was to help Nebraska farmers learn about potential opportunities with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

"We woke up on third base on the sustainable aviation issue. There are states that aren't to first base," Flood said. "God made Nebraska for corn."

Sustainable aviation fuel is essentially ethanol for aviation. To meet environmental standards, carbon dioxide, a byproduct of ethanol production, has to be captured and buried underground. Nebraska has a more developed infrastructure for this process compared to neighboring states like Iowa and South Dakota.

While some see opportunities to make money, not everyone in agriculture agrees that sustainable aviation fuel is beneficial.

"What they're talking about, in terms of sustainable aviation fuel, is a fairy tale," said Trent Loos, rancher and political activist.

Loos also objects to tax credits for the industry.

"They say that it costs too much to be competitive. In what industry do we try to prop something up to be competitive when it's not competitive?" he said.

CO2 pipeline opponents often raise concerns about safety.

"You know, for years and years and years, we've had these debates about underground pipelines. They are the safest," Flood said.

Michael Gibbern, president of the Nebraska Corn Growers Association, believes SAF would boost the agricultural economy, especially with current low corn prices.

"Economically, for sustainable aviation fuel to be a viable option and to get it off the ground, no pun intended, it's gonna take some government help. Some tax credits," Gibbern said.

Flood compared SAF to the rise in ethanol production a generation ago.

"Well, look at what Nebraska and the Feds did in the early part of the 2000s where we had the EPIC program that jump-started ethanol plant production in Nebraska," Flood said.

Unlike Iowa, the potential use of eminent domain for CO2 pipelines hasn't been a major issue in Nebraska.

This story was reported on-air by a journalist and has been converted to this platform with the assistance of AI. Our editorial team verifies all reporting on all platforms for fairness and accuracy.

Download our apps today for all of our latest coverage.

title: Vietjet hợp tác cùng Petrolimex sử dụng nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững SAF
description:
Lần đầu tiên tại Việt Nam, Petrolimex Aviation phối trộn và cung cấp toàn bộ 1.200 m³ SAF đầu tiên cho các chuyến bay của Vietjet, đánh dấu cột mốc quan trọng trong việc sản xuất và sử dụng nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững tại Việt Nam.
Petrolimex Aviation cũng chuyển giao Bằng chứng bền vững (Proof of Sustainability-PoS) theo tiêu chuẩn ISCC EU, cam kết bảo đảm nguồn nhiên liệu này đáp ứng các tiêu chuẩn quốc tế khắt khe về tính bền vững và giảm phát thải CO₂.
Trước đó, ngày 17/10/2024, Vietjet đã phối hợp cùng Petrolimex Aviation thực hiện hai chuyến bay đầu tiên được tra nạp SAF tại Việt Nam.
Được sản xuất từ nguyên liệu tái tạo và có nguồn gốc bền vững như dầu ăn đã qua sử dụng, phụ phẩm nông nghiệp, sinh khối gỗ, rác thải đô thị…, nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững SAF có thể giúp cắt giảm 80% lượng khí thải carbon so với nhiên liệu truyền thống, đáp ứng các tiêu chuẩn hàng không quốc tế nghiêm ngặt, sử dụng an toàn trong hoạt động khai thác thương mại.
Ông Tô Việt Thắng, Phó Tổng giám đốc Thường trực Vietjet cho biết: “Thỏa thuận giữa Vietjet và Petrolimex Aviation thể hiện cam kết của hai doanh nghiệp, ngành hàng không hướng tới các mục tiêu phát triển xanh, bền vững.
text:
Phát biểu ý kiến tại lễ ký thỏa thuận hợp tác giữa Vietjet và Petrolimex Aviation tại Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Cục trưởng Hàng không Việt Nam Uông Việt Dũng đánh giá: “Việc ra mắt sản phẩm SAF không chỉ có ý nghĩa về mặt thương mại mà còn mang ý nghĩa chiến lược lâu dài, tạo tiền đề xây dựng chuỗi cung ứng SAF bền vững trong nước; đáp ứng yêu cầu của thị trường quốc tế; khuyến khích hợp tác giữa các hãng hàng không, đơn vị cung cấp nhiên liệu, cơ quan quản lý và các tổ chức tài chính nhằm mở rộng quy mô sử dụng SAF tại Việt Nam”.

Lần đầu tiên tại Việt Nam, Petrolimex Aviation phối trộn và cung cấp toàn bộ 1.200 m³ SAF đầu tiên cho các chuyến bay của Vietjet, đánh dấu cột mốc quan trọng trong việc sản xuất và sử dụng nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững tại Việt Nam.

Petrolimex Aviation cũng chuyển giao Bằng chứng bền vững (Proof of Sustainability-PoS) theo tiêu chuẩn ISCC EU, cam kết bảo đảm nguồn nhiên liệu này đáp ứng các tiêu chuẩn quốc tế khắt khe về tính bền vững và giảm phát thải CO₂.

Theo Chủ tịch Hội đồng quản trị Tập đoàn Petrolimex Phạm Văn Thanh, Petrolimex đã chủ động đầu tư, nghiên cứu, làm chủ công nghệ pha chế SAF tại Tổng kho Xăng dầu Nhà Bè, đồng thời là đơn vị đầu tiên tại Việt Nam nhập khẩu SBC-hydrocarbon được tổng hợp từ nguyên liệu có nguồn gốc sinh học/tái tạo dùng để sản xuất SAF.

Thành công này thể hiện cam kết mạnh mẽ của Tập đoàn trong hành trình chuyển đổi xanh, đồng hành cùng Chính phủ, các hãng hàng không và toàn xã hội hướng tới phát triển bền vững.

Trước đó, ngày 17/10/2024, Vietjet đã phối hợp cùng Petrolimex Aviation thực hiện hai chuyến bay đầu tiên được tra nạp SAF tại Việt Nam. Được sản xuất từ nguyên liệu tái tạo và có nguồn gốc bền vững như dầu ăn đã qua sử dụng, phụ phẩm nông nghiệp, sinh khối gỗ, rác thải đô thị…, nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững SAF có thể giúp cắt giảm 80% lượng khí thải carbon so với nhiên liệu truyền thống, đáp ứng các tiêu chuẩn hàng không quốc tế nghiêm ngặt, sử dụng an toàn trong hoạt động khai thác thương mại.

Ông Tô Việt Thắng, Phó Tổng giám đốc Thường trực Vietjet cho biết: “Thỏa thuận giữa Vietjet và Petrolimex Aviation thể hiện cam kết của hai doanh nghiệp, ngành hàng không hướng tới các mục tiêu phát triển xanh, bền vững. Với tổng cộng 576 tàu bay hiện đại đã đặt hàng, đội bay xanh của Vietjet sử dụng SAF sẽ góp phần giảm đáng kể lượng khí thải, bảo vệ môi trường, tiên phong sử dụng nhiên liệu sạch, góp phần hiện thực hóa khát vọng phát triển, vươn mình trong kỷ nguyên hội nhập toàn cầu của đất nước”.

Vietjet là hãng hàng không tiên phong thực hiện chuyển dịch xanh, là hãng hàng không đầu tiên có báo cáo phát triển bền vững ESG, Vietjet sẽ tiếp tục thúc đẩy sử dụng SAF và góp phần thực hiện thành công Chiến lược quốc gia về tăng trưởng xanh, các mục tiêu giảm phát thải ròng về 0 vào năm 2050, phát triển bền vững cùng kỷ nguyên mới của đất nước.

title: Could sustainable aviation fuel take off for Nebraska agriculture? - PLATTE VALLEY
description:
ASHLAND – Nebraska is poised to become a national leader in aviation fuels made from renewable energy sources like corn and soybeans, but Congressman Mike Flood said there is work ahead.
Flood: “We woke up on third base on the sustainable aviation issue.
Caldwell: “Nebraska could be a great place for making sustainable aviation fuel, for putting a facility here to make the product.
One, we have a state leadership that’s very much in favor of expanding our value-added opportunities for our grains -- and that would be sustainable aviation fuel.
We are and can be what Iowa is to ethanol in sustainable aviation fuel.” Flood credited Tallgrass for its ability to engage Nebraskans to gain support for converting a natural gas pipeline into a Co2 pipeline.
text:
ASHLAND – Nebraska is poised to become a national leader in aviation fuels made from renewable energy sources like corn and soybeans, but Congressman Mike Flood said there is work ahead.

He said the Nebraska Legislature’s move in 2021 to enable ethanol plants to sequester and store carbon dioxide has given the state an advantage.

Flood: “We woke up on third base on the sustainable aviation issue. There are states that aren’t to first base. We’ve got this pipeline running across Nebraska that puts us in the driver’s seat, now we just need to take advantage of it and deliver.”

Dawn Caldwell of conference host Renewable Fuels Nebraska said the ability to capture and store carbon dioxide is a priority for potential airline customers.

Caldwell: “Nebraska could be a great place for making sustainable aviation fuel, for putting a facility here to make the product. We have a few things in our favor. One, we have a state leadership that’s very much in favor of expanding our value-added opportunities for our grains -- and that would be sustainable aviation fuel. Two, we have the feedstock.”

Flood said although the Big Beautiful Bill signed by President Donald Trump reduced incentives for sustainable aviation fuels from $1.75 to $1 a gallon, it did extend incentives for the clean fuel until 2029.

Flood: “There’s more work to be done, but I think as this nascent opportunity grows there’s going to be growth in sustainable aviation sales and we in Nebraska should lead the way.”

Conference speakers noted the role government energy incentives had in boosting the ethanol industry at the turn of the century and said sustainable aviation fuel could be the development that supports the next generation of Nebraska agriculture.

Caldwell: “Does Nebraska make sense, absolutely. Can we get there with our state legislation incentives, with whatever federal incentives may come along and garner that major private investment that is necessary to put the business in Nebraska? That up for the companies to go find, but we believe we’re in a really good spot.”

Flood said the conference comes at the dawn of a new market for Nebraska ag products.

Flood: “What I wanted to have happen today is for a farmer to leave here and the corn growers to leave here and say ‘when we talk ethanol we need to talk SAF. When we talk SAF we need to talk biofuels. We are and can be what Iowa is to ethanol in sustainable aviation fuel.”

Flood credited Tallgrass for its ability to engage Nebraskans to gain support for converting a natural gas pipeline into a Co2 pipeline.
